conclusion: To compare internal energy at states a and c, analyze the p-V diagram processes.
The cycle consists of two adiabatic processes (c to b and d to a) and two isochoric processes (b to c and a to d).
In an adiabatic process, no heat is exchanged; work done changes internal energy.
In an isochoric process, volume is constant; work done is zero; change in internal energy is due to heat exchange.
For isochoric process, temperature change is related to heat as \( Q = nC_v \Delta T \).
Internal energy of an ideal gas depends only on temperature.
Comparing internal energies at states a and c involves comparing their temperatures.
At state c, the gas is at a higher pressure and volume compared to state a.
During adiabatic expansion from c to b, internal energy and temperature decrease.
During adiabatic compression from d to a, internal energy and temperature increase.
From c to b (adiabatic expansion), temperature decreases.
From b to c (isochoric process), heat is added to increase temperature back to that at state c.
From d to a (adiabatic compression), temperature increases.
From a to d (isochoric process), heat is removed to decrease temperature to that at state d.
Temperature at state a is lower than at state c due to processes involved.
Internal energy at state a is less than at state c.
